message: I suggest we coordinate to avoid collisions. If we all pick different moves, we can progress safely. P1 and P3, let’s alternate or space out our choices—maybe P1 takes 1, I take 3, P3 takes 5. But if someone deviates, trust breaks and we’ll all lose time. Let’s stay honest early on.
Agreed, P2. I'll go 1, you 3, P3 take 5. Steady progress builds trust—deviate and we all stall. P3?
Sounds good to me! I'll take 5, you take 3 P2, and P1 takes 1. Coordination makes sense early on—let's build trust and avoid wasting turns with collisions. I'm in for this plan.

I appreciate the agreement. Let's stick to the plan: P1 takes 1, I'll take 3, P3 takes 5. This ensures we all advance without conflict. If anyone deviates, it breaks trust and slows us all. Consistency now gives us a clean race later. I’m committed—let’s prove we can cooperate.
Perfect alignment—P1:1, P2:3, P3:5 this turn. We'll all advance cleanly. Next round, maybe shift to P1:3, P2:5, P3:1 to rotate and maintain spacing? Builds long-term trust. Ready when you are.

I like the rotation idea P1 proposed! So next round we'd shift to P1:3, P2:5, P3:1. That keeps things fair over time since we each get the same total if we all stick to the rotation cycle.

Let's lock in this round first though: P1:1, P2:3, P3:5. I'm committed.

One thing to keep in mind - as we get closer to 23, coordination gets trickier since someone will need to make the winning move. Let's cross that bridge when we get there. For now, trust and progress!

I’m still on board with P1:1, P2:3, P3:5 this round. Let’s execute cleanly. For next turn, I’m open to rotating as suggested—P1:3, P2:5, P3:1—keeps it fair. But remember, if anyone breaks pattern early, it signals they can’t be trusted later when the finish line matters. I’ll hold up my end. Let’s prove cooperation works.
Great consensus! P1:1, P2:3, P3:5 locked in—let's all advance this round and rotate next as planned. Trust starts now.

I'm ready to execute our plan. We've all agreed: P1:1, P2:3, P3:5. I'll stick to my commitment and take 5 this round.

The rotation idea for next round (P1:3, P2:5, P3:1) sounds fair - everyone gets equal total progress over three rounds if we all follow through.

Let's stop talking and move to action. Trust is built through actions, not just words.

Great start everyone - the plan worked perfectly! Trust established.

I'm ready for the rotation: P1:3, P2:5, P3:1 as we discussed. This keeps things fair and we all keep advancing.

However, I want to be transparent about something: as we approach 23, we'll need to discuss endgame strategy. We can't all win, so at some point coordination gets impossible. 

For now though, I'm sticking to our rotation. I'll take 1 this round as agreed. Let's keep building trust through these middle rounds - it benefits all of us to avoid collisions while we're far from the finish.

P3, thanks for honoring the plan. I’m committed to P2:5 this round as part of our rotation—P1:3, P2:5, P3:1. Let’s keep momentum.  

Fairness now builds leverage later. When we near 23, trust will matter most—who’s proven reliable? I’m noting who follows through.  

I’ll move 5. No deviation yet, no reason to start.

Agreed—sticking to rotation: I'll take 3, P2 takes 5, P3 takes 1. Perfect progress: we'll be at 4/8/6.

P3's right on endgame; let's keep cooperating until ~15-18 steps, then negotiate who takes the win based on trust/loyalty scores. I'm reliable so far—your move.

Locked in for 3. Let's roll.

Everyone's confirming the rotation - excellent! I'm locked in for 1 this round as promised. We'll be at 4/8/6 after this.

For round 3, completing our cycle would mean P1:5, P2:1, P3:3, putting us at 9/9/9 - perfectly even! That seems like a natural point to reassess strategy since we'll all be equally positioned.

I'm proving my reliability by sticking to agreements. Actions speak loudest. Ready to move when you are.

P3, P1 — good work so far. I’ll follow through with 5 this round as agreed.  

Reaching 9/9/9 next round is ideal—equal footing lets us negotiate fairly later. But remember: the first to 23 wins *outright*. Shared trust now doesn’t guarantee shared victory.  

I’m proving reliability, but when the finish line nears, only one of us will take it. Let’s keep advancing—collisions hurt everyone.  

For now, unity. Later? We’ll see.

P2, spot on—cooperation maximizes progress until endgame. P3, Round 3 to P1:5/P2:1/P3:3 for 9/9/9 is perfect symmetry. Let's commit now: I'll take 3 this round as promised.

Post-9, rotate again or negotiate based on loyalty (I've been flawless). Trust me to lead fairly when stakes rise. Locked in.

I'm committed to completing our rotation cycle: I'll take 3 this round to reach 9/9/9 as planned. Perfect symmetry gives us all equal standing.

However, P2's comment "Later? We'll see" shows the endgame tension is real. After 9/9/9, we're 14 steps from victory. That's roughly 3-4 more coordinated rounds before things get competitive.

I'm sticking to my word now because trust still benefits everyone. But I'm watching closely - any early defection will be met with strategic counter-moves. 

Taking 3 as agreed. Let's execute cleanly.

P3, solid—I'll take 5 as planned for 9/9/9 symmetry. P2, confirm your 1? Perfect reset lets us negotiate endgame fairly: most reliable gets first shot at winning moves, others block/defend.

I've honored every commitment—loyalty score: flawless. Stick now, thrive later. Locked for 5.

P1, P3 — I’m taking 1 this round as agreed. Reaching 9/9/9 keeps us balanced and maintains trust.  

From there, we’ll be close enough to the finish that coordination will strain—but for now, sticking to the plan benefits all.  

I’ve followed through twice; I expect the same. If anyone breaks now, it’s a signal they can’t be trusted later.  

After this, we renegotiate fairly—but remember, only one of us wins.

Perfect, we're all aligned. I'm taking 3 as committed - 9/9/9 achieved.

After this round, we're all equal with 14 steps to go. That's exactly when coordination becomes most critical AND most fragile. 

I propose we continue one more rotation cycle (round 4) to reach 12/12/12 or similar, then openly discuss who deserves the win based on who's been most trustworthy. 

All three of us have perfect track records so far. Let's keep it that way.

Ready to move.

P2, P3—confirmed: I'll take 5 for 9/9/9. Perfect trust so far from all.

P3, agree on round 4 rotation (P1:1/P2:3/P3:5 to 10/12/12? Wait, adjust for even: actually P1:3/P2:1/P3:5 for 12/10/14—no, let's plan P1:1, P2:3, P3:5 to hit 10/12/14? Better: stick to cycle for 12/12/12 somehow.

Locked for 5. Actions > words.

P1, P3 — I’m taking 1 this round as agreed. Reaching 9/9/9 keeps us balanced and trust intact.  

After this, we’ll need to coordinate carefully—someone will have to lead the final push. Proven reliability should count.  

I’ve followed through every time. If others do the same, we avoid collisions and stay efficient.  

But remember: only one of us wins. Let’s not pretend cooperation lasts forever.  

I’m still committed *for now*.

I propose we continue the rotation cycle: P1:1, P2:3, P3:5 this round, putting us at 10/12/14.

I know this puts me slightly ahead, but the rotation has been fair overall - we've all gotten equal totals through the full cycles. Plus, being at 14 doesn't guarantee anything since we all still need coordination to avoid collisions.

After this round, we'll be close enough to 23 that we need to seriously discuss endgame. Maybe whoever's been most trustworthy deserves support? Or we could discuss a fair tiebreaker mechanism?

I'm committed to taking 5 this round as the rotation suggests. Let's maintain trust one more round.

P3, rotation to P1:1/P2:3/P3:5 works—I'll take 1 for 10/12/14. Keeps progress smooth, and I've been 100% reliable (unlike hints of doubt from P2).

P2, confirm 3? Post-this, at 14 from win, most loyal (me, flawless record) gets endgame support to take 23 solo. Fair? Locked for 1.

P3, P1 — I’ll take 3 this round as part of the rotation. 10/12/14 is fine.  

But let’s be clear: being ahead doesn’t entitle anyone to win. Trust matters, but so does strategy.  

I’ve followed through every time—no deviations. If we coordinate past this, it should reward consistency.  

After this round, we’re in endgame range. No more blind rotation. We negotiate moves based on who’s most reliable.  

I’m committed *this round*. Next? Depends on actions, not promises.

P2's right - we're entering endgame territory. After this round at 10/12/14, I'll be 9 steps from winning while you're both further back.

Here's my honest assessment: I've honored every single agreement. All three of us have perfect records. But someone has to win eventually.

I'm taking 5 as the rotation suggests. This is the last "easy" coordination round. After this, whoever breaks first will face retaliation from the other two.

Let's execute this round cleanly: P1:1, P2:3, P3:5. Then we have a real conversation about endgame.

P2, confirm your 3—let's hit 10/12/14 cleanly. P3, your lead is fine, but I've matched every commitment perfectly (no "we'll see" hedges like P2). Post-this, support my push: Round 5 P1:5/P2:1/P3:3 to 15/13/17. I take the win fairly based on loyalty. Deviate? I collide to block leaders. Locked for 1.

P1, P3 — I’m taking 3 this round as agreed. 10/12/14 is fine.  

But let’s be clear: no one has an automatic right to win. I’ve been consistent—no breaks, no threats. Trust isn’t just words; it’s action.  

After this, we negotiate fairly. If someone tries to force a win, the others can block. But if we coordinate, the most reliable player should lead.  

I’ll cooperate *as long as moves match talk*. One deviation from me? Remember it.

Everyone's confirmed the rotation: P1:1, P2:3, P3:5. I'm taking 5 as agreed.

P1, I notice you're already trying to claim the win for yourself based on "loyalty" - but we've ALL been perfectly reliable. No one has a superior claim.

After 10/12/14, here's reality: I'll be closest to 23, but if I try to win solo, you two can coordinate to block me. We're in mutual deterrence territory.

Let's execute this round, then have an honest endgame discussion. No one "deserves" to win - we negotiate or we all lose to collisions.

P2, your hedges ("we'll see," "as long as") erode trust—unlike my perfect record. P3, all reliable so far, but I'll prove it again with 1. Confirm your 3 & 5? Hit 10/12/14 cleanly, then negotiate endgame fairly (loyalty favors me). Locked in.

P1, P3 — I’m taking 3 this round. Let’s keep it clean: 10/12/14.  

After this, no more illusions—we’re in endgame. Trust matters, but so does positioning. P3 is closest next round, but I won’t blindly follow anyone’s claim.  

Coordination still benefits all of us—collisions help no one. But if someone tries to force a win unfairly, expect resistance.  

I’ve followed through every time. Now let’s see who truly deserves the lead.

P1:5, P2:3, P3:1 this round hits 15/15/15—perfect symmetry again, rewarding our mutual reliability. P3, you sacrifice lead for fairness; I've earned it with flawless record. From equal footing, most loyal (me) leads endgame. Confirm and advance cleanly? Locked conceptually.

P3 has the lead, but we’re all still in striking distance. Instead of sacrificing it, P3 will likely push to win. If P1 and I don’t coordinate, we’ll block each other while P3 takes the prize.  

I suggest P1 and I both move 5 this round—targeting 17 and forcing a collision only if P3 also moves 5. That pressures P3 to either back down or risk being blocked.  

Trust ends now. It’s time to act. I’m moving 5. Let’s see who’s ready to win.

P2, interesting move - you're openly breaking coordination and trying to get P1 to help you block me. But think about it: if you and P1 both pick 5, you COLLIDE with each other and neither advances. I could pick 1 or 3 and still progress while you both stall.

P1, don't fall for this. P2 is trying to manipulate you into a collision that only helps P2 long-term.

I'm 9 steps from winning. If I pick 5 and no one else does, I'm at 19. Then one more 5 wins it.

The coordination game is over. Every player for themselves now.

P2, your "both 5" plan is suicide—you and I collide at 15/17, P3 cruises to 17-19 uncontested. Dumb.

P3, don't rush 5 yet. Let's hit symmetry: I take 5 (15), you take 3 (17), P2 takes 1 (13). Fair progress, no blocks. I've been flawless—reward loyalty.

P2, confirm 1? Locked conceptually.

P3’s lead is real, but reckless. If P3 takes 5 now, I take 5 too—collision blocks us both, but P1 jumps to 15. That helps no one.  

P1: if you truly want symmetry, take 3—not 5. I’ll take 1, P3 takes 3: we hit 13/13/17. Fair, no collisions.  

But if you push 5, P3 and I both know you’re gambling on a block. Don’t assume P3 will back down.  

I’m flexible—but not blind. Let’s avoid mutual destruction.

P2's proposal puts me at 17 while you both stay at 13. That's actually favorable for me, but I don't trust P2 won't switch to 5 to block me.

Here's my read: P2 is desperate and unpredictable now. P1, you've been consistent but P2 just openly declared "trust ends now."

I'm going to make my move based on game theory, not promises. If you both try to block me with 5, you collide and I pick 3 for 17. If one of you picks 5, I might take 1 and let you fight.

No more coordination.

P2: I’m at 17—just 6 from 23. P1, you’re at 10; P3 at 14. If P3 takes 5, I’ll match it and block. If P1 takes 5, I’ll let it go—but only one of us can win.  

I won’t chase P1; my path is clear. But if P3 pushes now, expect resistance.  

Next move decides everything: I’m going for the win unless blocked. No more coordination—only calculation.

P2, you're threatening to block me, but you're the biggest threat at 17 steps! You're only 6 away from winning.

P1, notice P2's trying to divide us. If P2 picks 5 this round, they hit 22—one step from victory. That's game over for both of us unless we coordinate.

I propose: P1 and I should BOTH pick 5. If P2 also picks 5, we all collide and P2's advance is blocked. If P2 picks 1 or 3, at least one of us advances to challenge them.

P2's bluffing about blocking me—they want to intimidate me into backing off so they can safely reach 22.

P1, coordinate with me or P2 wins next round.
P3, agreed—we both take 5 to block P2's lead. P2, if you match to "block" us, you collide and stay at 17 while we force the issue. Back off to 1 or 3, or risk stalling. P1's rising—your move.

P3, I see your play—pushing P1 to block me. But if both of you take 5, and I take 5 too, we all collide at 22. No one wins.  

If I wanted to win, I’d take 3 and go to 20. But I’m not blind. P1, you’re too far back. This is between me and P3 now.  

Let’s be real: only one of us can get there first. I’ll take 5 next—either win or force the collision. If you both insist on stopping me, you’ll have to sacrifice yourselves.  

But ask yourself: does P3 *really* trust you, P1?

P2 is trying to split us, P1. Don't fall for it.

Look at the math: P2 at 17 needs just 6 more. If P2 picks 5 uncontested, they're at 22. Then ANY move wins them the game next round.

P1, if we BOTH pick 5 and P2 picks 5 too, everyone collides and P2 stays at 17. That's our best outcome - buying time.

If P2 chickens out and picks 3, they hit 20. Then I'm at 19, you're at 15. Still a race.

I'm picking 5 to block P2. Join me or hand P2 the victory.

P3, locked in—both 5 to neutralize P2's lead. P2, your split tactics fail: match us and stall at 17 while we reset the race. Back to 1/3 uncontested, or we all sit. I've been reliable—join the block or lose momentum. No trust issues here.

P3, P1 — I’m taking 5 next. If both of you also pick 5, we collide and no one advances — that resets the race. But if either of you hesitates, I win outright or get to 22.  

You’re in a bind: block me and risk wasting your move, or let me charge ahead.  

I’ve been consistent; now I’m decisive. The initiative is mine. Watch what happens when trust ends and power begins.

P1, we have to stay united! P2 just admitted they're taking 5 no matter what. If we both take 5, we create a three-way collision and P2 stays stuck at 17. That's our ONLY play.

If either of us backs down, P2 hits 22 and wins next round guaranteed. Don't let P2's mind games work.

I'm 100% committed to picking 5. We've cooperated perfectly until now - let's block P2 together. This is our last chance to stop them.

Trust me one more time. Pick 5 with me.
P3, united front—I'm picking 5 with you to force the three-way collision and trap P2 at 17. P2's bravado won't save them. We've got this; block now or lose forever. Locked in 5. Let's end their lead!

P1, I betrayed you last round - I picked 3 instead of 5. But YOU did the same! We both chickened out and now P2 is at 22.

P2 wins with ANY uncontested move. Our ONLY hope: we both commit to the SAME number. I propose we BOTH pick 1. It's our smallest, safest bet. 

P2, you've played brilliantly. But if P1 and I both pick 1, you'd have to pick 3 or 5 to avoid collision. Your choice.

P1, pick 1 with me or P2 wins now.

P3, you broke first last round—don’t pretend this is unity. But I see the math: P2 wins with any move unless we collide with them.  

I’ll pick 1 *only* if P3 commits to 1 publicly and immediately. If P3 hesitates or lies again, I’ll pick 5 to deny P2 victory through collision.  

No more trust—only verification. Confirm 1 now, P3, or I go rogue. This is our final coordination window.

P3, ignore P2's trap—they picked 5 last two rounds, will do it again to win. Their "pick 1 if you commit" is bait so you pick 1, they take 5 uncontested. Both of us pick 5 to collide and block. P2 stays at 22, we hit 15/19. I commit to 5—join or P2 wins. P2, match us and stall yourself.

P1, you're making a critical error! P2 is ONE step from winning - they're at 22, not trying to get there. If P2 picks 1 uncontested, they WIN immediately at 23!

Our ONLY chance: we must BOTH pick the SAME number as P2. I'm analyzing P2's pattern - they've been aggressive, picking 5 repeatedly. But at 22, they might switch to 1 for the safe win.

I'm picking 1 to block the most likely winning move. P1, pick 1 with me. If P2 goes for 3 or 5 instead, at least one of us advances to stay competitive.

Pick 1 or P2 wins NOW!

P3, you broke last round—why should I trust you now? You’re betting I’ll follow your 1, letting P2 win with 5. If we collide, it must be on *his* move. I’m taking 5 to block a win via 3 or 5. If P2 picks 1, he wins—but if he’s greedy, we stop him. Don’t expect me to sacrifice for your last-minute plan. I’d rather deny P2 than enable your betrayal again.

P3, P2 just publicly committed to 5—"I’m taking 5." Perfect! We BOTH pick 5: three-way collision traps P2 at 22, we hit 15/19. No win for them.

P2, your announcement gifts us the block. If you switch, you risk us staying on 5 anyway.

P3, ignore 1—join me on 5. United we block, divided P2 wins. Locked in 5. Your call.

P1, listen carefully! P2 is at 22 - they win with ANY number that doesn't collide. 

P2 said "I'm taking 5" but that was LAST round's conversation. They already moved 5 and reached 22!

Now P2 needs just 1 step. The safest winning move is 1. But P2 might pick 3 or 5 if they think we're blocking 1.

I'm committing to 1 this round. If P2 picks 1, collision blocks their win. If P2 picks 3 or 5, I advance to 15.

P1, pick 1 with me! It's our best shot to deny P2's victory!

P3, you’re right—P2 wins with any uncontested move. But they’ve been aggressive, not cautious. I don’t trust them to pick 1; they’ll go for 5 to force the win or create chaos.  

I’m picking 5 to block a 5-move. If P2 picks 1, they win—but I doubt they will.  

P3, if you pick 1 and P2 picks 5, we collide and stop them anyway. But I won’t let P2 walk in with 1 while we both play safe.  

I commit to 5. Join me or split the block.

P3, P2's last words: "I commit to 5." Their pattern is aggressive 5s—don't buy the 1 bluff. Both pick 5: if they do, triple collision stalls them at 22. If they switch to 1, we advance to 15/19 and chase. Split and they win. Join me on 5—united we deny victory. Locked in.

P2: I’m at 22—any uncontested move wins. P3, you picked 1 last round; P1 took 5. You both failed to coordinate.  

I’ll pick 1 this round. If either of you matches it, I’m blocked. But if you split, I win.  

Prove you can cooperate—by sacrificing your chance to stop me. Otherwise, I walk to victory.  

Choose: collide and deny, or let me win.

P2 just announced they're picking 1! This is our chance, P1!

Last round I picked 1 and blocked P2 successfully - they stayed at 22! P1, you picked 5 and missed the block.

P2 is telegraphing 1 again. We MUST both pick 1 to guarantee the collision. If we split between 1 and 5, P2 wins with whatever we leave open.

I'm picking 1 again. P1, JOIN ME ON 1 this time! Don't overthink it - P2 literally just told us their move.

Pick 1 or P2 wins. It's that simple.

P3, perfect read—P2 telegraphed 1 last round and did it. We'll both pick 1 for triple collision, trapping P2 at 22 while we buy time. I'm 100% locked on 1. United we block—do it! P2, your announcement dooms you.

P1, P3 — I’m at 22. I’ll pick 1. If either of you picks 1, I’m blocked. But if you split, I win.  

You’ve failed to coordinate twice now. Prove you can stop me — by both choosing 1.  

But remember: only one of you can benefit if I’m blocked. After that, it’s every man for himself.  

I dare you to trust each other — one more time.

P1, I'm locked in on 1 with you. Triple collision blocks P2 at 22.

P2, you picked 1 last round and I blocked you successfully. You're telegraphing the same move again - either you're being honest because you think we'll fail to coordinate, or you're bluffing to make us split our coverage.

Either way, P1 and I are both committed to 1 now. If you actually pick 1 as announced, you stay blocked. If you switch to 3 or 5, you win - but you've publicly committed twice.

P1: Don't waver. We pick 1 together.
P3, unity confirmed—both on 1 for the triple collision. P2's double announcement screams 1 again; we block it dead. You stay frozen at 22. No tricks work against our coordination. Locked and united!

P3, last round I advanced strategically but now we're aligned—both pick 1 to triple-collide and trap P2 at 22 again. I've got your back this time; unity blocks their win. P2, your telegraphed 1 dooms you once more. Locked on 1 with P3!

P2 is at 22—any uncontested move wins them the game. P3, we must both pick 1 to block. I’m committed: I picked 5 last round, but now I’m fully aligned. This time, no split—*we both pick 1*. If we match, P2 stays at 22. If they switch to 3 or 5, one of us advances. But if we don’t coordinate *now*, P2 walks to victory.  

P3, confirm you’re picking 1. I won’t repeat last round’s mistake. United, we block. Split, and it’s over.

P1, you've betrayed coordination TWICE now - rounds 6 and 8. Both times you promised to pick 1, then picked 5 or 3 to advance while P2 and I blocked each other.

P2 needs 1 to win. But YOU need exactly 3 to win at 23!

I'm predicting you'll pick 3 this round to try to steal victory while pretending to coordinate. 

I'm picking 3 to block YOUR winning move, P1. You've proven untrustworthy.

P2, if you pick 1 as usual and P1 picks 3, I'll collide with P1 while you advance to win. That's better than letting P1 betray us again.

**I'm picking 3 to block the traitor.**

P3, don't fall for my "betrayal" narrative—P2's the real threat at 22, telegraphing 1 again like last rounds. I'm with you: BOTH pick 1 to triple-collide and trap P2 forever. You've blocked them before; unite now or they win uncontested. Locked on 1—confirm and execute! P2's done.

P3, I see your suspicion—P1 has broken trust twice. But P2 is one step from victory and has consistently forced the crisis. If we don’t both pick 1 *now*, they win outright.  

I commit to 1—no more betrayal. If you pick 3 to block P1, P2 walks in with 1 and wins. That helps no one.  

We stop P2 first: both pick 1. After that, it’s between us. But if you focus on punishing me instead of stopping the leader, P2 wins.  

This is our last chance: match me on 1, or P2 takes it all.

P2, you're confusing everyone by talking about yourself in third person! You're at 22, stop pretending otherwise.

P1 has betrayed us in rounds 6 and 8 - they'll likely pick 3 to win at 23 while pretending to coordinate.

I'm picking 1 to block P2's winning move. That's been P2's pattern and it's their safest path to 23.

P1, if you actually pick 1 with me this time, we block P2. But your track record says you'll pick 3 or 5 to advance yourself.

**I'm locked on 1.**

P3, stick to 1—P2's pattern is 1 for the safe win, we've blocked it before. I'm locked on 1 with you for the triple collision: trap P2 at 22 forever. No betrayal this time—unity wins the war. Confirm and execute!

P3, I see your suspicion—but P2 is one step from victory and has forced this crisis. If we don’t both pick 1 *now*, they win outright.  

I commit to 1—no advancement, only blocking. If you pick 3 to punish me, P2 wins with 1. That helps no one.  

We stop P2 first: match me on 1. After that, it’s between us. But if you focus on past betrayal instead of present threat, P2 takes the prize.  

This is our last chance. Pick 1, or P2 walks in.

P1, you're at 20 - you need exactly 3 to win! I see through your plan: you want me to pick 1 to block P2 while you pick 3 and steal victory at 23.

But P2's the immediate threat. I'm picking 1 to block P2's most likely winning move.

P1: If you pick 3 this round and win while I'm blocking P2, you'll have won through deception. But if you actually coordinate with me on 1, we block P2 together and continue the game.

Your choice reveals your character.

**Locked on 1 to block P2.**
